Award.AwardTitle: Probing non-Abelian Quasiparticles with Johnson Noise Limited Measurements
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical description:
Until not long ago, it was thought that the large number of phases observed in condensed matter systems has a unifying underlining theory of phases. In the late 1980's it became apparent, however, that the so called topologically ordered phases are beyond this conventional understanding. Because of new fundamental physics and applications to novel types of quantum memories and to quantum computing, the non-Abelian topological phases have generated a lot of excitement. Nonetheless, the observation of such non-Abelian particles remains elusive in spite of extensive theoretical work and sustained efforts in measurements. The goal of this project is to look for experimental signatures of non-Abelian particles, novel particles harbored by non-Abelian phases, using electronic detection of the highest sensitivity. This project offers an excellent opportunity to train graduate and undergraduate students in modern electron physics, semiconductor nanofabrication, cryogenics, and introductory quantum computing, skills which are useful for a successful carrier in science and technology. The PI has involved and will continue to work with students from underrepresented groups. Furthermore, middle and high school students throughout the state of Indiana will be reached through the development of demonstrations and inquiry based activities with the hope of inspiring them to embark on a career in the sciences and engineering.

Technical description:
The study of the quantum phases with topological order has become one of the most exciting topics in condensed matter physics. One special type of topological quantum phase may harbor non-Abelian quasiparticles, a fundamentally new type of particles. Non-Abelian quasiparticles differ significantly from the well-known bosons and fermions since they have a fraction of the electron's charge and are predicted to obey non-Abelian statistics. In spite of a well-developed theory and sustained efforts in experiment, there is little progress towards an unambiguous detection of such non-Abelian quasiparticles. The PI proposes experimental research and education addressing outstanding questions on the nature of non-Abelian phases realized in the two-dimensional electron gas hosted in GaAs/AlGaAs quantum wells, specifically on the non-Abelian fractional quantum Hall states. Using our newly developed SQUID-based amplifier we will perform incisive measurements close to the Johnson noise limit. Our experiments offer a rare chance of demonstrating the existence of a new breed of particles with non-Abelian statistics and will contribute to a better understanding of other intensely studied topological phases realized in superconductor-semiconductor hybrid structures, topological superfluids and superconductors, topological insulators, and exotic atomic condensates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding phases of matter has been an important endeavor both for scientific discovery and for technological applications. Examples include harnessing of steam power during the industrial revolution, the use of superconductors in MRI machines, and the use of permanent magnets as digital memories in the hard drives of personal computers. Until not so long ago all phases of matter could be categorized and understood in terms of a well-known umbrella theory called Landau?s theory.

In the last 20 years or so, however, it was realized that there are new phases which do not fit into Landau?s description. These phases are called topological phases and they catalyzed a new paradigm in the understanding the material world. The understanding of these topological phases became one of the important efforts in contemporary condensed matter physics. Theoretical work is largely focused on classifying the known topological phases, on searching for completely novel types of topological phases, and on finding applications of these states. It is thought that topological phases may find use in low dissipation electronics, spin electronics, and quantum information science.

Many of the prototype topological phases, such as the integer and fractional quantum Hall states, were discovered in the two-dimensional electron gas. The two-dimensional electron gas continues to be a fascinating system, since recent theories predict it hosts a large number of very unusual topological phases. Certain phases are thought to have curious non-commutative properties which do not exist in any other known system and which may be harnessed for novel schemes of quantum memories and computation.

Many of the unusual topological states, however, are fragile and can only be detected at extremely low temperatures. The PI has built a unique instrument capable of reaching 0.005 Kelvin, one of the lowest electronic temperatures in the world. In addition, the PI developed low noise electronics uniquely suited for measuring faint electric signals. By taking advantage of these instruments, for this project we conducted experimental research and education outreach addressing outstanding questions on the nature of topological order in electron fluids realized in the two-dimensional electron gas, specifically in the exotic fractional quantum Hall states. These measurements involved device fabrication using modern lithographic techniques of high quality samples grown via molecular beam epitaxy and transport measurements at ultra-low temperatures.

The most exciting outcome of this project has been the discovery of an unusual signature in the strength of the one of the most exciting fractional quantum Hall state at the quantum number 5/2. The strength of this state, as quantified by the so called energy gap, was found to undergo an unexpected abrupt change. This abrupt change in the gap is not yet currently explained, but it indicates the occurrence of a phase transition in this state. If confirmed, such a phase transition would fundamentally contribute to the understanding of topological phases.

We also studied one of the most interesting region of the phase space near the state with quantum number 5/2. In this region several developing topological states were recently reported. We were able to confirm two such states. However, several other signatures turned out to be an artifact of another type of ground states called charge ordered states. These findings will impact future research on topological states in the GaAs/AlGaAs system, but also in other high quality electronic hosts of current interest, such as graphene and ZnO.

In addition, we developed low noise electronics capable of resolving signals that cannot be measured using standard room temperature electronics. While applications for such sensitive instruments will have to wait, measurements of faint electric signals of the topological phases are expected to uncover new information about these states.

During this project, besides the training of two graduate students Ethan Kleinbaum and Vidhi Shingla, a good number of other students were also engaged. In particular, the project has supported Edward Roob, an undergraduate student. Edward worked on developing a kit used for demonstrating electrical conduction in pure metals, alloys, semiconductors, and superconductors. His work culminated in a manuscript currently under peer review. Other undergraduate students were engaged during classes on nanotechnology. We have also interacted with the general public, mostly middle- and high school students and their parents, during events such as the Purdue SpringFest and the Purdue Nanodays.
